headline.main: WESTERN MARYLAND.; The Opening Spring--Cumberland, Its Inhabitants and the Scenery Round About It--A Secesh Family--Rebel Music and Poetry--Our Troops Gen. Kelly--New-Creek--An Encampment--Distinguished Officers--Bush Rangers--The sixth Virginia Regiment--The Cheat Mountain Country and its Magnificent Scenery--Artists and Sportsmen--Trout Fishing in the Mountains--Harper's Ferry Crossing--Col. Dixon. H. Miles--A Fac Simile of the Dora" of Porte Crayon.

docs.lead_paragraph: The weather, for the past two or three days, has been beautiful, and the foliage has come forward with great rapidity. Even in this mountainous section of country, which usually is far behind the seasons of lower latitudes, the ground is carpeted with verdure, and the little flowers peer forth from their nooks between the rocks, reminding one that the Spring-time is verging into Summer.

docs.snippet: The meeting of conservative Members of Congress, in accordance with the cail read in the House on Friday, was held at the Capitol on Saturday. Hon. JOHN J. CRITTENDEN, of Kentucky, presiding.

headline.main: NEWS FROM WASHINGTON.; The Conservative movement in Congress. THE PLATFORM TO BE ADOPTED. Arrival of National Prisoners from Richmond. Probable Flight of the Rebel Government. OUR SPECIAL WASHINGTON DISPATCHES FROM GEN. HALLECK'S ARMY. THE BATTLE OF SHILOH PROBABLE FLIGHT OF JEFF. DAVIS RETURN OF NATIONAL PRISONERS AN ERROR ABOUT GEN. DIX THE NEW-ORLEANS COLLECTORSHIP DEATH OF A MISSIONARY DEATH OF HON. SAMUEL F. VINTON. A PRISONER SHOT.

docs.lead_paragraph: MOVEMENTS OF CONSERVATIVE CONGRESSMEN. The Committee appointed by the Congressional Caucus of yesterday had a meeting last night, and talked over their programme, and Mr. CRITTENDEN, the Chairman, was requested to draw up some reso- lutions for an adjourned meeting of the committee to-morrow morning, at 10 o'clock.

keywords.value: CIVIL WAR (THE WAR BETWEEN THE STATES)

docs.snippet: It was predicted and expected by the Southern Press, and Southern clergymen, even, that New-York would be deluged with vice, crime, and bloodshed, when the war for the Union should once begin.
docs.abstract: editorial on British attitudes throughout war; Editorial on NYC morals in wartime; editorial on Fremont command and some of his men; Editorial on Southern attitudes and their treatment of Northerners
docs.lead_paragraph: It was predicted and expected by the Southern Press, and Southern clergymen, even, that New-York would be deluged with vice, crime, and bloodshed, when the war for the Union should once begin.

docs.snippet: We have again to announce the adjournment of the Legislature of this State without the enactment of the New-York Health bill. As there has been a widespread interest in this measure, it is but right that we should explain the course of legislative...
docs.lead_paragraph: We have again to announce the adjournment of the Legislature of this State without the enactment of the New-York Health bill. As there has been a widespread interest in this measure, it is but right that we should explain the course of legislative action in regard to it, and the causes of its ultimate failure.

docs.snippet: A brigade of rebels is encamped on the opposite side of the river, about six miles below Fredericksburgh. Contrabands who came in to-day say it is Gen. FIELDS'.
